utterances: Gillibrand notes that Sweeney supported free trade PACs like CAFTA that she says have taken jobs from the region.
But whether voters will blame Sweeney for the region's economy is unclear.
Marilyn Berkockley(ph), an administrative assistant, says she worries about healthcare.
Still, she likes Sweeney.
My son had a minor problem with a business that he owns in the area, and he was able to go to Sweeney's office and talk to a person there.
And I think that's an important thing.
He's always been very available around in this area.
That's exactly the way Republicans hope voters will see this year's races, as referendums on local issues and individual politicians.
But Democrats say there's also broader concern about where the economy is going.
The question is whether there's enough unease to tip the balance in some competitive races.
Jim Zarroli, NPR News.
The PGA Championship begins today.
It is golf's final major championship of the year and it'll be played at the Medinah Golf Club outside Chicago.
Phil Mickelson is defending the title that he won a year ago, while most of the pre-tournament attention is focused on his arch rival, Tiger Woods.
Commentator John Feinstein joins us now.
John, good morning again.
Good morning, Steve.
Wasn't too long ago that people were saying Mickelson, not Woods, was about to become the world's number one player.
Well, standing on the 18th tee at Wingfoot at the U.S.
Open in June with a one-shot lead about to win his third major championship in a row, it certainly looked that way, didn't it?
Right after Tiger Woods had missed the cut, his first major cut missed ever in the wake of his father's death.
And Mickelson, as we all know, blew up, double-bogeyed that hole, lost the Open.
And since then Tiger Woods is on one of those rolls he gets on.
He won the British Open easily.
He won at the Buick Open a couple of weeks ago, easily.
His last eight rounds of golf, Steve, he's been 42 under par.
That's roughly the equivalent of going a month in baseball hitting .500.
And this is a golf course that plays to his strengths.
He won the PGA Championship at Medinah in 1999.
It's a par 72.
That means four par fives, and that's a big advantage for Tiger.
When Tiger gets on one of these streaks, does the rest of the field give up?
They don't give up, but they're certainly intimidated.
There's no question.
Sergio Garcia played with Tiger Woods in the last round at the British Open and he had that deer in the headlights look from the first tee on.
And I think it's because the other players know Tiger Woods at his best is better than everybody else.
It's simple as that.
And right now, it appears that he's at his best.
Now, what happens to Phil Mickelson?
He's a guy who had a reputation for losing tournaments at the end.
Then he started winning.
And then he had this disaster at the U.S.
Open you were describing.
Yeah.
That's a very good question, because it looked like he was, again, on this role.
He'd won three majors out of nine, looked like he was going to make it four, then he blows up.
He was a non-factor at the British Open.
He's been a non-factor since June.
I'm always concerned, Steve, when I hear an athlete say, well, my children still love me, because that's irrelevant to the conversation.
Of course his children still love him.
And when you hear an athlete sort of rationalizing defeat that way, it says to me that he hasn't dealt with the loss yet.
And until he looks the loss right in the eye and says I screwed up, he's not going to be a factor again.
We'll see what happens this weekend in Chicago.
You know, looking at that U.S.
Open a couple of months ago, I mean the guy played terrible the entire day.
It was amazing that he was still in contention at the end.
It was heroic that he was still in contention at the end.
Well, it was a brutally tough golf course.
And remember, the winning score was five over par.
So everybody struggled that day, you're right.
He only hit two fairways, which is why it was so ridiculous for him to hit the driver on the 18th hole.
And his initial reaction, Steve, I thought was encouraging: I was an idiot.
But since then, he's sort of backed off on that.
And he's sort of made excuses.

It reminds a little bit of Greg Norman when he blew the sixth shot lead at the Masters in '96 and initially said, oh, you know, I blew it, and then came back and said, well, I only hit two bad shots all day.
That's rationalizing.
Now, after the PGA tournament, which begins today, the U.S.
selects its Ryder Cup team to play against the Europeans.
How's that shaping up?
Alan Greenblatt of Governing magazine.
His article, ""What is the Age of Responsibility?"" And Laurence Steinberg, a professor of Psychology at Temple University who studies the problem of behavior in adolescent development.
Delta Airlines has just four of these planes to inspect.
A spokesman there says most inspections can be performed during overnight stops, so these planes don't even have to be taken out of service.
And what might happen might there be any further action once investigators take a closer look at what happened with these planes?
Yeah, that's exactly the question we put to the FAA spokesman today.
Les Dorr told us this is an ongoing process.
This is the first part of what could be a several part puzzle.
Both we and Boeing are continuing to assess the situation.
If in fact it turns out that there are other issues we need to address or when a permanent fix is developed, we won't hesitate to take what action we need to.
By the way, this apparently isn't the first time this problem has come up.
There's a report that back in 2005 Boeing received four reports of a nut - from this wing assembly coming loose.
Boeing even determined back then that the loose nut could cause a fuel leak.
It sent a service letter out, but a service letter doesn't require action.
This new directive from the FAA does.
And it means that there will be an inspection every 3,000 flights.
Thank you so much, Bob.
Bob Moon of public radio's daily business show, MARKETPLACE.
It's produced by American Public Media.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
This time of year kids are playing ball, they're jumping through sprinklers, they're riding their bikes, and they're forgetting much of what they learned in school last year.
Research indicates low-income school kids lose an average of two months of reading achievement over the summer.
As NPR's Larry Abramson reports, that's a big reason for the achievement gap between whites and minority children.
If you think of summer as a time for exploration, a time to be a kid, it may be because your family had some resources.
Ron Fairchild of the Center for Summer Learning says poor kids begin to slide after school lets out.
Low-income kids lose more than two months of reading performance each year of their elementary school years.
And those losses accumulate.
During the school year, educators struggle to bridge the so-called achievement gap between white and minority kids.
But Fairchild and other experts say parents can give their kids a leg-up by sending them to programs like SuperKids.
(Soundbite of children)
Tory, a rising second-grader, is attending the SuperKids program at the Midtown Academy in downtown Baltimore.
It looks and feels like a day camp for second and third graders, but a lot of the fun is focused on reading and math.
(Soundbite of children)
SuperKids accept kids like Tory from any Baltimore school.
They're only just learning to read, but are already in danger of falling behind as summer progresses.
Fred Coleman(ph) teaches in the Baltimore city schools during the regular school year.
My goal is to - when they get back to school, they haven't lost anything.
Do you see that in your regular teaching job, that when the kids come back in September, they're not where they were, they're not where you left them?
Yes, just like you're starting all over again in terms of the curriculum and skill building.
Parks and People, a local non-profit, runs the camp.
Executive director Jacqueline Carrera says the staff spends the first few days figuring out where kids need help, and most need quite a bit.
The majority of the kids are at least one grade level or more behind by the time they come to us, which is saying something because they're only going into the second and third grade.
Parks and People is a recreation program at heart, so there are plenty of sports and outdoor games built into the day.
In fact, the organization has to stitch together grants for sports, arts and academics in order to put this camp together.
Summer learning advocate say it's hard to find money that is dedicated to providing a full time enrichment program over the long summer break.
They say most schools spend all the funding they have before the end of the year and only offer remedial summer school, which is seen as a punishment.
Summer learning studies say these programs work best when there's follow-up at home.
That's what affluent kids are getting from enriched summer programs or from reading books with their parents.
Amy Airs(ph), whose eight-year-old daughter is spending the summer at SuperKids, says she encourages reading all summer long.
Yes, we read, we often visit the library and she gets a new book.
We try to keep her box of vocabulary words filled.
And I'll give her a nickel for each correct word.
And if she, you know, gets it right.
And if she misses the word the next day, I'll take the nickel back, so she doesn't like giving me money back.
Airs works in Baltimore's Department of Juvenile Services.
She knows what happens to kids who fall behind or to those for whom summer is a time to build a career in the drug trade.
So supporters of these programs say don't shed any tears over the death of summer vacation.
Lots of kids just use that time to get into trouble.
Larry Abramson, NPR News.
